title: 110_hr288
content: The Act titled "Notch Baby Act of 2007" establishes a new guaranteed minimum primary insurance amount for those eligible during a transitional period. Section 215(a) of the Social Security Act is amended to include provisions for individuals eligible for old-age insurance benefits between 1978 and 1989, ensuring a transitional increase amount is factored into their primary insurance amount calculation. The text outlines the percentage of benefits individuals are eligible for based on the year they become eligible, ranging from 60 percent in 1979-1980 to 10 percent in 1987-1988. It also defines 'excess under former law' as the difference between the former law primary insurance amount and the recalculated amount without certain considerations. The text explains how the 'applicable former law primary insurance amount' is determined for individuals based on specific calculations under different circumstances, with adjustments made as outlined in subparagraphs (D) and (E). The text outlines the calculation of the 'applicable former law primary insurance amount' for individuals, with adjustments made as specified in subparagraphs (D) and (E), including provisions for individuals aged 61 and older. SEC. 3. EFFECTIVE DATE AND RELATED RULES. The amendments made by this Act are effective as if included in the Social Security Amendments of 1977, with no benefit increases before January 2007. Recomputation of benefits is required for individuals entitled to benefits in December 2006 based on specific provisions of the Social Security Act. The Commissioner of Social Security will recompute the primary insurance amount for individuals entitled to benefits in December 2006, taking into account the amendments made by this Act.
